description: RAG Database for English Grammar Restructuring - Natural Idiom Patterns for JP→EN Translation

contrastive_comparison.description: Comparing two subjects where both share a quality, but one is notable/surprising

patterns.japanese_structure: AはBだが、CもBだ / AはBけど、CはBだ
patterns.english_pattern: X is one thing, but Y is [quality]

examples.jp: 真理亜は変だが、如月さんも結構変だ
examples.literal: Maria's weird, but Kisaragi-san is pretty weird in her own right
examples.natural: Maria's one thing, but Kisaragi-san is pretty weird in her own right

examples.jp: 先生は厳しいが、校長先生はもっと厳しい
examples.literal: The teacher is strict, but the principal is even stricter
examples.natural: The teacher is one thing, but the principal is on another level

examples.jp: 兄は背が高いが、弟はさらに高い
examples.literal: My brother is tall, but my younger brother is even taller
examples.natural: My brother is one thing, but my younger brother towers over everyone

usage_rules: Use when both subjects share the same quality
Second subject exceeds/matches in surprising way
Especially effective with も (also/too) in Japanese

patterns.japanese_structure: だけでなく / ばかりでなく
patterns.english_pattern: not just X, but Y / not only X but (also) Y

examples.jp: 彼女は美しいだけでなく、頭もいい
examples.literal: She is not only beautiful, but also smart
examples.natural: She's not just beautiful—she's brilliant too

usage_rules: Use em dash (—) for emphasis in casual writing
'not just' is more conversational than 'not only'

patterns.japanese_structure: はおろか / どころか
patterns.english_pattern: let alone X / much less X / never mind X

examples.jp: 歩くどころか、立つこともできない
examples.literal: Forget about walking, I can't even stand
examples.natural: I can't even stand, let alone walk

usage_rules: 'let alone' is most natural in modern English

dismissive_acknowledgment.description: Acknowledging something while dismissing its importance

patterns.japanese_structure: Aはともかく / Aは置いといて

examples.jp: 君はともかく、彼女は絶対怒る
examples.literal: Putting you aside, she would definitely get mad
examples.natural: You're one thing, but she'd definitely get mad

usage_rules: Use when dismissing first subject to focus on second

emotional_intensifiers.description: Japanese emotional markers that need restructuring in English

patterns.japanese_structure: めちゃくちゃ / 超 / すごく + adjective

examples.jp: めちゃくちゃエロい
examples.literal: extremely lewd
examples.natural: crazy lewd / insanely hot
examples.context: Casual speech, light novel protagonist internal monologue

usage_rules: Match register: めちゃくちゃ → crazy/insanely (casual)

examples.jp: 絶対に行く
examples.literal: I will absolutely go
examples.natural: I'm going for sure / I'm so going / No way I'm missing this

examples.jp: 絶対にダメ
examples.literal: Absolutely no
examples.natural: No way / Not happening / Over my dead body

examples.jp: 絶対だよ？約束して
examples.literal: It's absolute, okay? Promise me
examples.natural: Promise me, okay? For real / You better promise / Swear to me

examples.jp: 絶対勝つ
examples.literal: I will absolutely win
examples.natural: I'm winning this / I'll win no matter what / Count on me winning

usage_rules: Promise: use 'I swear', 'for real', 'cross my heart'
Determination: use 'no matter what', 'for sure', intensified verb
Match character voice: masculine → 'damn right', feminine → 'for sure'

patterns.english_pattern: Context-dependent: exasperation vs negation vs agreement

examples.jp: まったく、しょうがないな
examples.literal: Really, it can't be helped
examples.natural: Good grief / Honestly / Jeez, what am I gonna do with you

examples.jp: まったく知らない
examples.literal: I completely don't know
examples.natural: I have no clue / Don't know at all / Haven't the faintest idea

examples.jp: まったくだ。君の言う通りだ
examples.literal: Completely. You're saying it correctly
examples.natural: Exactly! / Tell me about it / You can say that again

examples.jp: まったくもう！
examples.literal: Really now!
examples.natural: Ugh! / Good grief! / I swear! / Honestly!

usage_rules: Complete negation: 'not at all', 'zero', 'haven't the faintest'
Agreement: 'exactly', 'tell me about it', 'ain't that the truth'
Consider character age/gender: older → 'good grief', younger → 'ugh'

high_frequency_transcreations.description: Most common Japanese expressions needing context-aware transcreation (based on 400K lines corpus analysis)

patterns.japanese_structure: やっぱり / やはり / やっぱ (confirmed expectation/reversion)
patterns.english_pattern: Context-dependent: confirmation vs reversion vs opinion

examples.jp: やっぱり彼女は可愛い
examples.literal: As expected, she is cute
examples.natural: She really is cute / Yeah, she's definitely cute

examples.jp: やっぱりやめる
examples.literal: As expected, I'll stop
examples.natural: Actually, never mind / On second thought, I'll pass

examples.jp: やっぱり俺がやる
examples.literal: As expected, I'll do it
examples.natural: You know what, I'll handle it / Actually, let me do it

usage_rules: Confirmed expectation: 'sure enough', 'definitely', 'just as I thought'
AVOID: 'as expected' except in formal/dramatic contexts

examples.jp: まあ、いいけど
examples.literal: Well, it's fine but
examples.natural: I guess that's fine / Fair enough / Sure, whatever

examples.jp: まあ、そうだな
examples.literal: Well, that's so
examples.natural: Yeah, I guess / Pretty much / Can't argue with that

examples.jp: まあまあだ
examples.literal: It's well-well
examples.natural: It's decent / Not bad / Could be worse

usage_rules: Sentence starter: often just 'Well,' or omit entirely

examples.jp: さすが真理亜だ
examples.literal: As expected of Maria
examples.natural: That's Maria for you / Classic Maria / Leave it to Maria

examples.jp: さすがにそれは無理
examples.literal: As expected, that's impossible
examples.natural: Even I can't do that / That's too much even for me / Come on, that's asking too much

examples.jp: さすがプロだな
examples.literal: As expected of a professional
examples.natural: Now that's a pro / Pros are something else / That's what a real pro looks like

usage_rules: AVOID: 'As expected of' - sounds unnatural in most contexts

patterns.japanese_structure: なんだか / 何だか (vague feeling)

examples.jp: なんだか嬉しい
examples.literal: Somehow I'm happy
examples.natural: I'm kinda happy / There's something nice about this / I don't know why but I'm happy

examples.jp: なんだか変だ
examples.literal: Somehow it's strange
examples.natural: Something's off / It feels weird somehow / There's something strange going on

usage_rules: Often can be omitted in natural English

examples.jp: 別に気にしてないし
examples.literal: I'm not particularly caring
examples.natural: It's not like I care / Whatever / Doesn't bother me

examples.jp: 別にいいよ
examples.literal: It's particularly fine
examples.natural: Sure, whatever / Fine by me / Go ahead, I don't mind

examples.jp: 別に...そういうわけじゃない
examples.literal: It's not particularly like that
examples.natural: That's not... I mean, it's not like that / It's not what you think

usage_rules: Match character personality for best effect

examples.jp: 確かにそうだ
examples.literal: Certainly that's so
examples.natural: You've got a point / Fair point / Can't argue with that

examples.jp: 確か彼女は大阪出身だった
examples.literal: Certainly she was from Osaka
examples.natural: If I remember right, she's from Osaka / She's from Osaka, I think

examples.jp: まさか、本当に来たの？
examples.literal: No way, did you really come?
examples.natural: Wait, you actually came? / Hold on, you're really here?

examples.jp: まさかそんなことが
examples.literal: No way such a thing
examples.natural: That can't be / There's no way / This can't be happening

examples.jp: まさかの展開
examples.literal: No way development
examples.natural: Plot twist / Unexpected turn / What a twist

patterns.japanese_structure: もしかして / ひょっとして (tentative guess)

examples.jp: もしかして、怒ってる？
examples.literal: By any chance, are you angry?
examples.natural: Are you... mad at me? / Wait, are you upset?

examples.jp: もしかして、好きなの？
examples.literal: By any chance, do you like (someone)?
examples.natural: Don't tell me you like them / Wait, do you have feelings for...?

usage_rules: Realization: 'Don't tell me...', 'Hold on, is this...?'

examples.jp: とりあえずビール
examples.literal: For the time being, beer
examples.natural: I'll start with a beer / Beer for now

examples.jp: とりあえず座って
examples.literal: For the time being, sit
examples.natural: Have a seat first / Why don't you sit down

examples.jp: とりあえずやってみる
examples.literal: For the time being, I'll try
examples.natural: Let me just try it / I'll give it a shot for now

patterns.japanese_structure: そもそも (in the first place/fundamentally)
patterns.english_pattern: Questioning premise or returning to basics

examples.jp: そもそも、なぜここに？
examples.literal: In the first place, why here?
examples.natural: Wait, why are you even here? / The real question is, why are you here?

examples.jp: そもそも俺は興味ない
examples.literal: In the first place I'm not interested
examples.natural: I was never interested to begin with / I wasn't interested from the start

usage_rules: Questioning: 'The real question is', 'Why even', 'Wait, why'
Original state: 'from the start', 'to begin with', 'never was'
Rhetorical: 'What's the point of' + original action

patterns.japanese_structure: 仕方ない / しょうがない (can't be helped)

examples.jp: 仕方ないな
examples.literal: It can't be helped
examples.natural: Well, what can you do / Guess there's no choice / Oh well

examples.jp: 仕方ないから手伝う
examples.literal: Because it can't be helped, I'll help
examples.natural: Fine, I'll help / Guess I have no choice but to help / Alright, alright, I'll help

usage_rules: Resignation: 'Oh well', 'What can you do', 'That's life'
Reluctant help: 'Fine, I'll [verb]', 'Guess I have to'
AVOID: literal 'It can't be helped' - sounds stiff

patterns.japanese_structure: せっかく (since you went to the trouble)

examples.jp: せっかく来たんだから
examples.literal: Since you went to the trouble of coming
examples.natural: Since you're already here / Now that you've come all this way

examples.jp: せっかく作ったのに
examples.literal: Even though I went to the trouble of making it
examples.natural: After all the effort I put into making this / And I worked so hard on this

usage_rules: Wasted effort: 'After all that effort', 'And I worked so hard'
Encouragement: 'It'd be a shame not to', 'Might as well'
Focus on the RESULT of effort, not the effort itself

patterns.japanese_structure: わざわざ (going out of one's way)

examples.jp: わざわざ来てくれたの？
examples.literal: Did you go out of your way to come?
examples.natural: You came all the way here? / You didn't have to come

examples.jp: わざわざ言わなくていい
examples.literal: You don't need to go out of your way to say it
examples.natural: You don't have to spell it out / No need to rub it in

usage_rules: Appreciation: 'all the way', 'You didn't have to'
Often implies the action was unnecessary or excessive

examples.jp: 結局、行かなかった
examples.literal: In the end, I didn't go
examples.natural: I ended up not going / I never did go

examples.jp: 結局それかよ
examples.literal: In the end, it's that, huh
examples.natural: So that's how it is / It all comes down to that, huh

usage_rules: Realization: 'So that's', 'It all comes down to'
Summary: 'Bottom line', 'At the end of the day'
Context determines tone: resigned vs matter-of-fact

examples.jp: 一応聞いておく
examples.literal: I'll tentatively ask
examples.natural: I'll ask just in case / Let me check to be safe

examples.jp: 一応、彼女だけど
examples.literal: Tentatively, she's my girlfriend but
examples.natural: She's technically my girlfriend / I guess you could call her my girlfriend

usage_rules: Implies not fully committed or uncertain

examples.jp: なるほど、そういうことか
examples.literal: I see, so that's how it is
examples.natural: Ah, that makes sense / Oh, I get it now / So that's what's going on

examples.jp: なるほどね
examples.literal: I see (casual)
examples.natural: Right, right / Makes sense / Gotcha

examples.jp: ちょっと待って
examples.literal: Wait a little
examples.natural: Hold on / Hang on / Wait up

examples.jp: ちょっと難しい
examples.literal: A little difficult
examples.natural: That's kind of tricky / A bit tough

examples.jp: ちょっと！
examples.literal: A little!
examples.natural: Hey! / Excuse me! / What gives?

usage_rules: Softening: 'a little', or often just omit

patterns.japanese_structure: そういえば / ところで / それより (topic change)

examples.jp: そういえば、明日は？
examples.literal: Speaking of which, tomorrow?
examples.natural: Oh, that reminds me—tomorrow? / Speaking of, what about tomorrow?

examples.jp: ところで、彼女は？
examples.literal: By the way, she?
examples.natural: Anyway, where's she? / So, what about her?

examples.jp: それより、大丈夫？
examples.literal: More than that, are you okay?
examples.natural: Forget that—are you okay? / Never mind that, you alright?

usage_rules: そういえば: 'That reminds me', 'Speaking of which'
それより: 'Forget that', 'Never mind that', 'More importantly'

examples.jp: どうもおかしい
examples.literal: Somehow strange
examples.natural: Something's definitely off / I can't shake this feeling

examples.jp: どうも
examples.literal: Somehow
examples.natural: Hey / Thanks / Hi there

usage_rules: Often can be omitted or absorbed into tone

patterns.japanese_structure: なんとか / どうにか (barely managing)

examples.jp: なんとか間に合った
examples.literal: Somehow made it in time
examples.natural: Just barely made it / Made it by the skin of my teeth

examples.jp: なんとかなる
examples.literal: It will somehow work out
examples.natural: It'll work out / We'll figure it out / We'll manage

examples.jp: なんとかして
examples.literal: Do something somehow
examples.natural: Do something! / Figure it out! / Make it work!

usage_rules: Optimism: 'It'll work out', 'We'll figure it out'

patterns.japanese_structure: ちなみに (additional info/by the way)

examples.jp: ちなみに、俺は行かない
examples.literal: By the way, I'm not going
examples.natural: For the record, I'm not going / Just so you know, I'm out

examples.jp: ちなみにこれ、手作り
examples.literal: By the way, this is handmade
examples.natural: This is homemade, by the way / Oh, and this is handmade

usage_rules: Clarification: 'For the record', 'Just so you know'
Can often move to end: '[statement], by the way'

logical_flow.description: Japanese logical connectors that need natural English equivalents

patterns.japanese_structure: だって / なぜなら at start of explanation
patterns.english_pattern: After all, ... / I mean, ... / It's just that ...

examples.jp: だって、真理亜は幼馴染だから
examples.literal: Because Maria is my childhood friend
examples.natural: After all, she's my childhood friend / I mean, Maria's my childhood friend

usage_rules: Use 'I mean' for clarification in casual speech
Don't start with bare 'Because' in English

emphasis_restructuring.description: Japanese emphasis particles that need English restructuring

patterns.japanese_structure: なんて / なんか with dismissive nuance
patterns.english_pattern: something like X / X or whatever / as if X

examples.jp: 彼女なんていらない
examples.literal: I don't need something like a girlfriend
examples.natural: I don't need a girlfriend or anything / Who needs a girlfriend?

usage_rules: Can be sarcastic or genuinely dismissive

double_negatives.description: Japanese double negatives that sound awkward in literal English

japanese_indicators: ないわけにはいかない

examples.jp: やらないわけにはいかない
examples.literal: It's not that I can't not do it
examples.natural: I have to do it / I can't just not do it

usage_rules: Prefer single positive statement when possible
Keep double negative only for emphatic effect

rhetorical_questions.description: Japanese rhetorical questions requiring English restructuring

patterns.english_pattern: right? / don't you think? / isn't it?

examples.jp: 変じゃない？
examples.literal: Isn't it weird?
examples.natural: That's weird, right? / Kinda weird, don't you think?

usage_rules: Place 'right?' at end for casual speech
Use 'don't you think?' for softer tone
Can restructure as statement + tag question

conditional_restructuring.description: Japanese conditional forms requiring natural English equivalents

patterns.english_pattern: if only X / as long as X / all you need is X

examples.jp: 君さえいれば、他に何もいらない
examples.literal: If only you are here, I don't need anything else
examples.natural: As long as I have you, I don't need anything else

usage_rules: 'all you need' works for positive emphasis

patterns.english_pattern: if X had [past], Y would have [past participle]

examples.jp: もっと早く来ていたら、彼女に会えただろう
examples.literal: If I came earlier, I could have met her
examples.natural: If I'd come earlier, I would've met her / Had I come earlier, I'd have met her

usage_rules: Use contracted forms for casual speech (I'd, would've)
Formal: can invert to 'Had I come...'

patterns.english_pattern: provided (that) / as long as / so long as

examples.jp: 約束を守る限り、手伝ってあげる
examples.literal: As long as you keep your promise, I'll help you
examples.natural: I'll help you, provided you keep your promise

usage_rules: 'as long as' is casual and common
Can place condition before or after main clause

perfect_aspect_nuances.description: Subtleties in perfect tense usage for completed actions with present relevance

examples.jp: 日本に行ったことがある
examples.literal: I went to Japan before
examples.natural: I've been to Japan / I've visited Japan

usage_rules: Use present perfect for indefinite past experience
Simple past only if specific time mentioned
'have been to' specifically for places visited

examples.jp: ずっと待っているんだ
examples.literal: I am waiting for a long time
examples.natural: I've been waiting forever / I've been waiting this whole time

usage_rules: Use for actions starting in past, continuing now

patterns.english_pattern: had already [past participle] / had [past participle] before

examples.jp: 彼が来る前に、私はすでに帰っていた
examples.literal: Before he came, I already went home
examples.natural: I'd already left by the time he arrived / I had left before he came

usage_rules: Use past perfect for earlier of two past events

modal_verb_subtleties.description: Nuanced modal verb usage beyond basic can/will/should

patterns.japanese_structure: ～てもいいかも / ～た方がいいかも
patterns.english_pattern: might as well / may as well

examples.jp: どうせ暇だし、行ってもいいかも
examples.literal: Since I'm free anyway, it might be good to go
examples.natural: I've got nothing better to do—might as well go

usage_rules: 'might as well' slightly more tentative than 'may as well'

patterns.english_pattern: should have [past participle] / ought to have [past participle]

examples.jp: もっと早く言うべきだった
examples.literal: I should say earlier
examples.natural: I should've said something sooner

usage_rules: Express regret about past action not taken
'should have' is more common than 'ought to have'

patterns.japanese_structure: むしろ～したい / ～の方がいい

examples.jp: 死ぬ方がマシだ
examples.literal: Dying is better
examples.natural: I'd rather die

parallel_structure.description: Creating balanced, rhythmic sentences through parallelism

patterns.english_pattern: not X but Y / not X—Y

examples.jp: 彼女は怒っているのではなく、悲しんでいる
examples.literal: She is not angry, she is sad
examples.natural: She's not angry—she's sad / She's not angry but heartbroken

usage_rules: Keep grammatical structure parallel (both adjectives or both verbs)
Can use em dash for dramatic pause
'but' is neutral, dash is more emphatic

examples.jp: 彼は来なかったし、電話もしなかった
examples.literal: He didn't come and also didn't call
examples.natural: He neither came nor called

usage_rules: More formal/literary than 'didn't X and didn't Y'
Can emphasize with 'neither X nor even Y'

subordinate_clause_restructuring.description: Transforming Japanese subordinate clauses into natural English

patterns.english_pattern: the fact that / that [clause] (can often omit 'that')

examples.jp: 彼女が来るということを知っている
examples.literal: I know the fact that she is coming
examples.natural: I know she's coming

usage_rules: Often drop 'the fact that' for cleaner prose
Can omit 'that' after verbs like know/think/say
Keep 'the fact that' only for emphasis

patterns.english_pattern: Restructure with who/which/that or split sentences

examples.jp: 昨日会った女の子はとても可愛かった
examples.literal: The girl whom I met yesterday was very cute
examples.natural: The girl I met yesterday was really cute

usage_rules: Split long relative clauses into separate sentences

active_passive_optimization.description: Choosing between active and passive voice for clarity

patterns.english_pattern: Prefer active voice unless actor is unknown/unimportant

examples.jp: 彼女に笑われた
examples.literal: I was laughed at by her
examples.natural: She laughed at me

usage_rules: Active voice is clearer and more direct
Keep passive only when focus is on receiver
Japanese uses passive more than English

examples.jp: 財布を盗まれた
examples.literal: My wallet was stolen
examples.natural: I got my wallet stolen / Someone stole my wallet

usage_rules: Often better to use active with indefinite actor

idiomatic_time_expressions.description: Natural time expressions beyond literal translation

patterns.japanese_structure: いつの間にか / 気がついたら
patterns.english_pattern: before I knew it / before you know it

examples.jp: いつの間にか寝ていた
examples.literal: Without noticing, I fell asleep
examples.natural: I fell asleep before I knew it / I drifted off without realizing

usage_rules: 'before I knew it' for past events

examples.jp: 昔はよくここに来た
examples.literal: In the past, I often came here
examples.natural: I used to come here all the time

usage_rules: 'used to' for past states/habits no longer true
Add 'all the time' / 'often' to emphasize frequency

sentence_rhythm.description: Creating natural flow and pacing in English prose

examples.jp: 信じられない。本当に信じられない。
examples.literal: I can't believe it. I really can't believe it.
examples.natural: Unbelievable. Just... unbelievable.

usage_rules: Fragments okay for emphasis in fiction

examples.jp: 今こそチャンスだ
examples.literal: Now is the chance
examples.natural: Now is the time / This is our chance

usage_rules: 'It is X that' cleft sentences for emphasis

character_voice_markers.description: Japanese character speech patterns needing English equivalents

patterns.japanese_structure: だぜ / だな / ぜ ending particles

examples.jp: すごいぜ
examples.literal: It's amazing
examples.natural: That's awesome, dude / Damn, that's amazing

usage_rules: Add casual interjections for masculine speech
Match character archetype (cool guy, nerd, etc.)
Don't overuse - every other sentence max

patterns.japanese_structure: わ / の / のよ ending particles
patterns.english_pattern: softened statements, use contractions + tag questions

examples.jp: 行くわよ
examples.literal: I'm going
examples.natural: I'm going, you know / Let's go already

usage_rules: Use contractions for feminine casual speech
Add 'you know' or tag questions for softness

advanced_patterns.description: Advanced grammar patterns for literary and sophisticated writing

subjunctive_mood.description: Subjunctive mood for hypothetical, wishes, and demands

patterns.japanese_structure: ～たらいいのに / ～ればいいのに
patterns.english_pattern: I wish X were / If only X were

examples.jp: 彼女がここにいたらいいのに
examples.literal: It would be good if she was here
examples.natural: I wish she were here / If only she were here

usage_rules: Use 'were' for all persons in formal subjunctive
'I wish' + had + past participle for past regret

patterns.japanese_structure: ～するよう要求する / ～べきだと主張する

examples.jp: 彼は私が行くよう要求した
examples.literal: He demanded that I go
examples.natural: He demanded that I go (not 'goes')

usage_rules: Use base form (not 'goes' but 'go') after demand/insist/suggest
Applies to: demand, insist, suggest, recommend, require

inversion_structures.description: Subject-verb inversion for emphasis and formality

patterns.japanese_structure: 決して～ない / めったに～ない

examples.jp: こんな美しい景色は二度と見られないだろう
examples.literal: I probably won't see such beautiful scenery again
examples.natural: Never again will I see such beautiful scenery / Seldom have I seen such beauty

usage_rules: Only with negative adverbs at start

examples.jp: もし私が知っていたら、教えていただろう
examples.literal: If I had known, I would have told you
examples.natural: Had I known, I would have told you

patterns.english_pattern: even though / despite / in spite of

examples.jp: 雨が降っているにもかかわらず、彼は出かけた
examples.literal: Despite the rain falling, he went out
examples.natural: Even though it was raining, he went out / He went out despite the rain

patterns.japanese_structure: いくら～ても / どんなに～ても
patterns.english_pattern: much as / however much / no matter how

examples.jp: どんなに頑張っても、できない
examples.literal: No matter how hard I try, I can't do it
examples.natural: However hard I try, I just can't do it / Much as I try, it's impossible

participial_phrases.description: Using participles for concise, sophisticated prose

examples.jp: 音楽を聴きながら、勉強した
examples.literal: While listening to music, I studied
examples.natural: Listening to music, I studied / I studied, listening to music

usage_rules: Participle and main verb must share same subject
Can place at start or end for emphasis

examples.jp: 驚かされて、彼は言葉を失った
examples.literal: Being surprised, he lost words
examples.natural: Shocked, he was speechless / Taken aback, he couldn't speak

usage_rules: Subject of participle = subject of main clause

nominalization_reduction.description: Avoiding excessive nominalization for clearer prose

examples.jp: 彼は速く走ることができる
examples.literal: He can do the running quickly
examples.natural: He can run fast

usage_rules: Exception: established phrases like 'make a decision'

patterns.english_pattern: Reduce to single verb when possible

examples.jp: 彼女の歌う行為は美しい
examples.literal: The act of her singing is beautiful
examples.natural: She sings beautifully / Her singing is beautiful

usage_rules: Reduce 'the act of [gerund]' to gerund alone
Convert noun phrases to verbs for clarity
Keep nominalization only for technical/legal writing

comedic_timing.description: Patterns for maximizing comedic impact through punchy, concise delivery - especially critical for romcom/ecchi comedy

patterns.english_pattern: Drop connecting words, use shorter sentence for punchline

examples.jp: こいつ、本が苦手というより頭を使うことが嫌いなんだよな
examples.literal: It's not that this girl hates books; she just hates using her brain.
examples.natural: She doesn't hate books. She hates thinking.

examples.jp: 真面目というより、単に融通が利かない
examples.literal: Rather than serious, he's simply inflexible
examples.natural: He's not serious. He's just inflexible.

usage_rules: Split into two short sentences for comedic beat
Second sentence is the punchline - keep it shortest
Drop softening language like 'rather', 'it's just that'
Let the contrast create the humor naturally

patterns.japanese_structure: どこの世界に～するヤツがいるんだ

examples.jp: どこの世界に人の部屋にやってきて、いきなり布団を敷き始めるヤツがいるんだ
examples.literal: Who in the world walks into someone's room and immediately starts laying out their futon?
examples.natural: Who just walks into someone's room and starts unrolling their futon?

usage_rules: Remove 'in the world' for punchier delivery
Drop modifiers like 'immediately' if they dilute impact

patterns.english_pattern: Use blunt noun compounds, avoid flowery description

examples.jp: もう、オスになった駿太の匂いを楽しんでたのに
examples.literal: Aw, I was just enjoying the scent of Shunta-turned-man.
examples.natural: I was enjoying your man-smell.

usage_rules: Blunt compound nouns are funnier than descriptions
Works for ecchi comedy and playful teasing

patterns.english_pattern: Reduce to colon format for deadpan delivery

examples.jp: おっぱいが見られないならこの旅館に用はない
examples.literal: Is it too heartless to think that if I can't see boobs, I have no business being at this inn?
examples.natural: Is it heartless to think: no boobs, no reason to be here?

usage_rules: Use colon to create comedic beat/pause
Parallel structure amplifies humor (X, no Y)

patterns.english_pattern: State absurd situations in plain language

examples.jp: 幼なじみでも、高校生にもなったらお互いの家なんて行かないでしょ
examples.literal: Childhood friends or not, when you're in high school, you don't really go to each other's houses.
examples.natural: Childhood friends or not, high schoolers don't really go over to each other's houses, you know.

usage_rules: Let situation be funny, not the language
Works for ecchi, comedy of errors, awkward situations

patterns.english_pattern: Drop softening, use short exclamation for reaction

examples.jp: どうしてそこで田中が出て来るんだよっ！
examples.literal: Why does Tanaka have to come up now?!
examples.natural: Why does Tanaka have to come up now?!

examples.jp: た……たた、田中ァァァ!! あのやろっ！　また適当なことをッッッ!!
examples.literal: T-T-Tanakaaa!! That bastard! Spreading nonsense again!!
examples.natural: T-T-Tanakaaa!! That bastard! Spreading nonsense again!!

usage_rules: Multiple exclamation marks for comedic intensity
Works for breaking romantic mood with absurdity

patterns.english_pattern: Use 'There's no way' or direct negation

examples.jp: 俺が優里亜のこと臭いとか思うわけないだろ！
examples.literal: There's no way I'd ever think Yuria smells bad!
examples.natural: There's no way I'd ever think Yuria smells bad!

examples.jp: 俺が女子に向かって『俺のち●ち●のサイズ枝豆の莢なんだ』なんて言うわけないだろ！
examples.literal: There's no way I'd ever tell a girl, 'My penis is the size of an edamame pod!'
examples.natural: There's no way I'd ever tell a girl, 'My penis is the size of an edamame pod!'

usage_rules: Keep the absurd detail in the quote

examples.jp: あーもう！　ち●ち●、ち●ち●うっさいし！
examples.literal: Ugh, enough! Penis, penis, you're so loud!
examples.natural: Ugh, enough! Penis, penis, you're so loud!

examples.jp: 太ももに関しては諒太が太もも太ももって言ってたからだし！
examples.literal: As for my thighs, that's because you kept saying 'thighs, thighs'!
examples.natural: As for my thighs, that's because you kept saying 'thighs, thighs'!

usage_rules: Don't smooth out for elegance - repetition IS the joke

examples.jp: ほんとさ、うちの犬の方が利口なのおかしいでしょ
examples.literal: Honestly, it's ridiculous how much smarter my dog is than you.
examples.natural: Honestly, it's ridiculous how much smarter my dog is than you.

examples.jp: そんな別に婚約を報告しに来たんじゃないんだから
examples.literal: It's not like you're here to announce our engagement or anything...
examples.natural: It's not like you're here to announce our engagement or anything...

usage_rules: Works for playful banter and teasing

rag_retrieval_strategy.description: How to retrieve patterns during translation

steps.name: Parse Japanese structure
steps.method: Identify particles, connectors, sentence patterns in source

steps.name: Match indicators
steps.method: Search pattern database for matching japanese_indicators

steps.name: Rank by priority
steps.method: High priority patterns take precedence, context-aware selection

steps.name: Inject into prompt
steps.method: Add matched patterns as few-shot examples before translation

steps.name: Post-process validation
steps.method: Check if LLM applied pattern correctly, suggest fixes if needed

phase_2_translation.action: Analyze source text, retrieve 3-5 most relevant patterns, inject as examples

phase_3_critics.action: Check if opportunities for natural idioms were missed, flag for revision

pattern_addition_workflow.description: How to add new patterns discovered during QA
steps: 1. Identify awkward literal translation in output
2. Find Japanese source pattern causing the issue
4. Add to appropriate category in this file

character_profiles.description: Link grammar patterns to character voice via manifest.json

implementation.integration_method: During Phase 2, read character profiles from manifest → filter patterns by character → inject character-appropriate examples
implementation.example_logic: If POV character uses 'ore' (masculine), prioritize masculine_casual patterns. If character is tsundere, boost dismissive_acknowledgment patterns.

benefits: No need to manually specify character traits per chapter

genre_specific.description: Adjust pattern priorities based on genre tags in manifest.json

romcom.tone: Punchy, blunt punchlines. Keep absurdity matter-of-fact. Preserve repetition for comedic effect.
romcom.avoid: Over-embellishing comedy, smoothing out awkward repetition, softening insults

ecchi.tone: Direct, no euphemisms. Let situations speak for themselves. Keep internal monologue grounded.
ecchi.avoid: Purple prose, flowery descriptions, over-explaining the joke

slice_of_life.tone: Natural, everyday speech. Emphasize warmth and relatability.

action.tone: Short, punchy sentences. Active voice. Immediate present tense for intensity.
action.avoid: Long descriptive passages during action, passive constructions

drama.tone: Allow longer, more introspective sentences. Emotional depth over brevity.
drama.avoid: Oversimplifying complex emotions, being too blunt

implementation.integration_method: Phase 2 checks manifest genres → adjusts pattern priority weights → LLM receives genre-appropriate examples

benefits: Reduces need for manual per-chapter instructions

vector_search.description: Use embeddings for semantic pattern matching and thematic tracking

phase_1.name: Semantic Pattern Matching
phase_1.method: Embed all pattern examples → during translation, embed source sentence → retrieve semantically similar patterns (not just keyword match)
phase_1.benefit: Catch patterns that don't match keyword indicators but have similar meaning

phase_2.name: Repetitive Theme Detection
phase_2.method: Embed all translated paragraphs per chapter → cluster by semantic similarity → identify repetitive themes/phrases
phase_2.benefit: Flag overused phrases ('seemed to', 'as if'), detect AI-ism patterns automatically
phase_2.use_case: Audit phase - generate heatmap of repetitive language density

phase_3.name: Cross-Volume Consistency
phase_3.method: Build vector index of all character dialogues across volumes → retrieve similar past translations for consistency
phase_3.benefit: Maintain character voice consistency across entire series

tools_required: Vector database (ChromaDB, FAISS, or simple numpy)
Cosine similarity threshold tuning per use case

frequency_tracking.description: Track which patterns are most commonly needed for training data
frequency_tracking.current_state: corpus_frequency field exists for high_frequency_transcreations (e.g., まあ: 3320, やっぱり: 2048)

next_steps.automated_tracking: During Phase 3 critic review, log which patterns were applied → increment usage counter
next_steps.pattern_suggestion: When audit finds awkward translation, analyze JP source → suggest which pattern should have been used
next_steps.feedback_loop: Patterns with high frequency but low application rate = priority for LLM fine-tuning examples
